newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian president opposes graft amnesty.
newsitem.headline: Italian president opposes graft amnesty.

text.p: President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro expressed opposition on Tuesday to an amnesty for defendants in Italy's multitude of corruption scandals.
The head of state made his position clear in a statement published after he met the speakers of the two houses of parliament for talks on a crisis in the Italian justice system.
The statement, issued by Scalfaro's office, said judicial reform should be undertaken in a way that avoided "solutions which wipe the slate clean and do not correspond to the canons of justice".
The phrase was a clear reference to renewed debate on how to move on from the corruption scandals that have shaken Italy since 1992 and brought down its old governing class.
Several politicians have argued that some form of amnesty should be proclaimed to close the matter.
Investigations by magistrates into alleged corruption in public life have dominated Italian affairs for four years.

Their conduct has blurred the separation of powers between parliament and the judiciary and heightened a sense among many Italians that the courts have become a battleground for settling political scores and for rivalry among magistrates.

The confusion was highlighted last week when prosecutors sent police to raid homes and offices of Antonio Di Pietro, a former star anti-graft magistrate who quit as a cabinet minister last month to fight allegations that he too was corrupt.
Di Pietro has called the inquiry a "squalid vendetta".
Many of Italy's leading politicians, including Prime Minister Romano Prodi and opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi, have been caught up in the judicial assault.
The sheer number of cases, running to more than 1,000, has also overwhelmed a trial system notorious for its slowness.
Scalfaro's statement indicated that parliament's speakers would take steps to ensure swift discussion of draft legislation on judicial reform and on the prevention and repression of corruption.

It was welcomed by the governing centre-left alliance as pointing the way to a more efficient justice system and criticised by Berlusconi's centre-right opposition as undue interference in the work of parliament.
